word/document.xml
I hope it’s obvious it was only the centrally controlled nature of those systems that doomed them.

word/document.xml

I think this is the first time we’re trying a decentralized, non-trust-based system.— Satoshi Nakamoto<x3/>Despite the incredible success of crypto, the question of whether the free market can establish a viable monetary system still arises.

I think this is the first time we’re trying a decentralized, non-trust-based system.— Satoshi Nakamoto<x3/>Despite the incredible success of crypto, the question of whether the free market can establish a viable monetary system still arises.
word/document.xml
It is often suggested that crypto is workable only because it exists in parallel with fiat with which it is convertible and upon which it rests.
It is often suggested that crypto is workable only because it exists in parallel with fiat with which it is convertible and upon which it rests.
word/document.xml
Does the institution of money ultimately require trusted third party oversight and the context of the state?
Does the institution of money ultimately require trusted third party oversight and the context of the state?
word/document.xml
(An institution is an established law, practice, or custom within a society.)<x4/>The question can be reduced to a more fundamental one.
(An institution is an established law, practice, or custom within a society.)<x4/>The question can be reduced to a more fundamental one.
word/document.xml
How does any institution within society arise, and how does it decline?
How does any institution within society arise, and how does it decline?
word/document.xml
The answer lies within the concepts of decentralization and centralization.<x5/><g2>What is Centralization?
The answer lies within the concepts of decentralization and centralization.<x5/><g2>What is Centralization?
word/document.xml
What is Decentralization?</g2><x6/>Centralization concentrates control of an activity or organization under a single authority in order to coordinate results.
What is Decentralization?</g2><x6/>Centralization concentrates control of an activity or organization under a single authority in order to coordinate results.
word/document.xml
In terms of the monetary monopoly, the activity is society; the authority is the state that coordinates the flow of finance with the stated goal of producing an efficient and productive economy.
In terms of the monetary monopoly, the activity is society; the authority is the state that coordinates the flow of finance with the stated goal of producing an efficient and productive economy.
word/document.xml
Another term for centralized control of society is “social engineering.”
Another term for centralized control of society is “social engineering.”
word/document.xml
The state applies theories of social science to the management of human beings in order to control their placement and functioning.
The state applies theories of social science to the management of human beings in order to control their placement and functioning.
word/document.xml
The social control is intended to achieve a society that is just or effective according to the vision of those in charge.<x7/>Not all centralization dismisses individual choice.
The social control is intended to achieve a society that is just or effective according to the vision of those in charge.<x7/>Not all centralization dismisses individual choice.
word/document.xml
Private businesses can centralize under one management team to increase profits, for example.
Private businesses can centralize under one management team to increase profits, for example.
word/document.xml
When they do so, they are often called corporations.
When they do so, they are often called corporations.
word/document.xml
The crucial difference between this scenario and state centralization is that businesses are voluntary, and the individuals involved are free to walk away to join a competitor.
The crucial difference between this scenario and state centralization is that businesses are voluntary, and the individuals involved are free to walk away to join a competitor.
word/document.xml
With social control, the individuals have no choice.
With social control, the individuals have no choice.
word/document.xml
Walking away constitutes breaking the law, and there is no competitor.<x8/>Decentralization is the diffusion of power away from a central authority down to its constituent units.
Walking away constitutes breaking the law, and there is no competitor.<x8/>Decentralization is the diffusion of power away from a central authority down to its constituent units.
word/document.xml
In the political arena, this means passing control from a national level down to a local one.
In the political arena, this means passing control from a national level down to a local one.
word/document.xml
Discussion of decentralization usually starts and stops in the political realm, with the power still vested in a coordinating authority.
Discussion of decentralization usually starts and stops in the political realm, with the power still vested in a coordinating authority.
word/document.xml

A local government may be better than a remote one because it is more responsive to the community, but the logical end point of decentralization is the individual who is the building block of all society and its most basic constituent unit.

A local government may be better than a remote one because it is more responsive to the community, but the logical end point of decentralization is the individual who is the building block of all society and its most basic constituent unit.
word/document.xml
This arrangement is both a method and a goal.
This arrangement is both a method and a goal.
word/document.xml
The method is the empowerment of the individual.
The method is the empowerment of the individual.
word/document.xml

The goal is a healthy society in which every member makes his own choices according to his own self-interest.<x9/>Centralization is so woven into the fabric of the culture that many people believe it is necessary for society to function.

The goal is a healthy society in which every member makes his own choices according to his own self-interest.<x9/>Centralization is so woven into the fabric of the culture that many people believe it is necessary for society to function.
word/document.xml
Public schools, central banks, the judiciary, public works, government roads, tariffs…
Public schools, central banks, the judiciary, public works, government roads, tariffs…
word/document.xml

most people cannot envision society through any lens other than centralized state control; it is all they have known and all they have been taught.<x10/>Throughout most of history, society has been viewed as the result of someone’s design.

most people cannot envision society through any lens other than centralized state control; it is all they have known and all they have been taught.<x10/>Throughout most of history, society has been viewed as the result of someone’s design.
word/document.xml
The designer might be God, a tribal chief, a monarch, a committee of socialists or communists, a team of experts, or some other entity that was the state misspelled.
The designer might be God, a tribal chief, a monarch, a committee of socialists or communists, a team of experts, or some other entity that was the state misspelled.
word/document.xml
Society was seen as an artificial construct created and managed by authorities.
Society was seen as an artificial construct created and managed by authorities.
word/document.xml

Society was deemed to be dependent upon a coordinating authority for its law, morality, and prosperity.<x11/>In his three-volume work <g3>Law, Legislation and Liberty</g3>, social theorist Friedrich Hayek refers to this position as “constructivist rationalism.”

Society was deemed to be dependent upon a coordinating authority for its law, morality, and prosperity.<x11/>In his three-volume work <g3>Law, Legislation and Liberty</g3>, social theorist Friedrich Hayek refers to this position as “constructivist rationalism.”
word/document.xml
A core constructivist belief is that man can and should consciously invent social institutions such as the law through the application of reason and social science.
A core constructivist belief is that man can and should consciously invent social institutions such as the law through the application of reason and social science.
word/document.xml
Hayek argues vigorously against this perspective, claiming that constructivists misunderstand the process by which the institutions of society evolve.
Hayek argues vigorously against this perspective, claiming that constructivists misunderstand the process by which the institutions of society evolve.
word/document.xml
Indeed, he believes the constructive approach is antithetical to the real process and hinders social institutions that should evolve rather than follow a blueprint.
Indeed, he believes the constructive approach is antithetical to the real process and hinders social institutions that should evolve rather than follow a blueprint.
word/document.xml

In a 1974 Nobel Memorial Lecture entitled “<g4>The Pretense of Knowledge</g4>,“ Hayek expresses a basic epistemological objection to constructivism—that is, an objection based on a theory of human knowledge.

In a 1974 Nobel Memorial Lecture entitled “<g4>The Pretense of Knowledge</g4>,“ Hayek expresses a basic epistemological objection to constructivism—that is, an objection based on a theory of human knowledge.
word/document.xml
He states that no committee can predict the evolving choices and unintended outcomes of a mass of people who interact over time.
He states that no committee can predict the evolving choices and unintended outcomes of a mass of people who interact over time.
word/document.xml

Human preference is too variable, and it changes in ways that thwart all planning.<x12/>To recycle a quotation from earlier in the book:<x13/>The recognition of the insuperable limits to his knowledge ought indeed to teach the student of society a lesson in humility which should guard him against becoming an accomplice in men’s fatal striving to control society—a striving which makes him not only a tyrant over his fellows, but which may well make him the destroyer of a civilization which no brain has designed but which has grown from the free efforts of millions of individuals.<x14/>Hayek’s contemporary, the Ludwig von Mises comes to the same conclusion from a less epistemological and more economic angle in his masterpiece <g5>Human Action.</g5><x15/>Human action originates change.

Human preference is too variable, and it changes in ways that thwart all planning.<x12/>To recycle a quotation from earlier in the book:<x13/>The recognition of the insuperable limits to his knowledge ought indeed to teach the student of society a lesson in humility which should guard him against becoming an accomplice in men’s fatal striving to control society—a striving which makes him not only a tyrant over his fellows, but which may well make him the destroyer of a civilization which no brain has designed but which has grown from the free efforts of millions of individuals.<x14/>Hayek’s contemporary, the Ludwig von Mises comes to the same conclusion from a less epistemological and more economic angle in his masterpiece <g5>Human Action.</g5><x15/>Human action originates change.
word/document.xml
As far as there is human action there is no stability, but ceaseless alteration…
As far as there is human action there is no stability, but ceaseless alteration…
word/document.xml
The prices of the market are historical facts expressive of a state of affairs that prevailed at a definite instant of the irreversible historical process…
The prices of the market are historical facts expressive of a state of affairs that prevailed at a definite instant of the irreversible historical process…
word/document.xml
.In the imaginary and, of course,<x16/>unrealizable state of rigidity and stability there are no changes to be measured.
.In the imaginary and, of course,<x16/>unrealizable state of rigidity and stability there are no changes to be measured.
word/document.xml
In the actual world of permanent change there are no fixed points…
In the actual world of permanent change there are no fixed points…
word/document.xml
Both Hayek and Mises believe that the knowledge sought by constructivists is unattainable.
<x17/>Both Hayek and Mises believe that the knowledge sought by constructivists is unattainable.
word/document.xml

It is not possible to plan the dynamics of tomorrow based on those of yesterday because people’s preferences and other circumstances are unforeseeable, even by the people involved; guesses are possible, but knowledge is not.

It is not possible to plan the dynamics of tomorrow based on those of yesterday because people’s preferences and other circumstances are unforeseeable, even by the people involved; guesses are possible, but knowledge is not.
word/document.xml

Even a small thing, like the price of bread yesterday does not give knowledge of the price of bread tomorrow because it might skyrocket due to a flour shortage or a change in people’s priorities.<x18/>Using a static photo of yesterday’s society to engineer the future goes against a basic tenet of human action and human nature: inevitable change.

Even a small thing, like the price of bread yesterday does not give knowledge of the price of bread tomorrow because it might skyrocket due to a flour shortage or a change in people’s priorities.<x18/>Using a static photo of yesterday’s society to engineer the future goes against a basic tenet of human action and human nature: inevitable change.
word/document.xml
Inevitable change is a fundamentally difference between human beings and the physical objects examined by the hard sciences upon which the constructivists based their social theory.
Inevitable change is a fundamentally difference between human beings and the physical objects examined by the hard sciences upon which the constructivists based their social theory.
word/document.xml
A scientist can learn everything he needs to know to predict the behavior of a rock because the rock is static over time.
A scientist can learn everything he needs to know to predict the behavior of a rock because the rock is static over time.
word/document.xml
Water continues to have the same molecular structure, and it continues to be defined by constants such as the law of gravity.
Water continues to have the same molecular structure, and it continues to be defined by constants such as the law of gravity.
word/document.xml
But society does not consist of invariable objects.
But society does not consist of invariable objects.
word/document.xml
The behavior of human beings is based on altering preferences, emotions, and psychological responses that can be conflicted or hidden even from the people who are acting.
The behavior of human beings is based on altering preferences, emotions, and psychological responses that can be conflicted or hidden even from the people who are acting.
word/document.xml
Human beings cannot be neatly categorized, stacked, and made to obey the laws of science.
Human beings cannot be neatly categorized, stacked, and made to obey the laws of science.
word/document.xml
Society consists of unpredictable individuals who react to changing circumstances.
Society consists of unpredictable individuals who react to changing circumstances.
word/document.xml
They are not rocks or water.<x19/>There are two ways for social theorists to approach the waywardness of unforeseeable man.
They are not rocks or water.<x19/>There are two ways for social theorists to approach the waywardness of unforeseeable man.
word/document.xml

They can accept the nature of human beings and work their theories around it, or they can try to change the nature of man to fit their theories.<x20/>Constructivists choose the later option, with the new Soviet Man or Soviet Person being one manifestation of their theories.

They can accept the nature of human beings and work their theories around it, or they can try to change the nature of man to fit their theories.<x20/>Constructivists choose the later option, with the new Soviet Man or Soviet Person being one manifestation of their theories.
word/document.xml
The new Soviet Man was deemed to be the logical evolution of human beings under communist rule.
The new Soviet Man was deemed to be the logical evolution of human beings under communist rule.
word/document.xml

In his book <g6>The Mass Psychology of Fascism </g6>(1933), the German psychoanalyst Wilheim Reich asks, “Will the new socio-economic system reproduce itself in the structure of the people's character?

In his book <g6>The Mass Psychology of Fascism </g6>(1933), the German psychoanalyst Wilheim Reich asks, “Will the new socio-economic system reproduce itself in the structure of the people's character?
word/document.xml
If so, how?
If so, how?
word/document.xml
Will his traits be inherited by his children?
Will his traits be inherited by his children?
word/document.xml
Will he be a free, self-regulating personality?
Will he be a free, self-regulating personality?
word/document.xml

Will the elements of freedom incorporated into the structure of the personality make any authoritarian forms of government unnecessary?”<x21/>Human nature, like society, would be reconstructed by those in power.

Will the elements of freedom incorporated into the structure of the personality make any authoritarian forms of government unnecessary?”<x21/>Human nature, like society, would be reconstructed by those in power.
word/document.xml
The new Soviet man was an archetype or ideal human being with specific characteristics that would be designed by and evolve out of communism.
The new Soviet man was an archetype or ideal human being with specific characteristics that would be designed by and evolve out of communism.
word/document.xml
The new human nature would be shared by all Soviet people irrespective of factors such as differing cultural or ethnic backgrounds.
The new human nature would be shared by all Soviet people irrespective of factors such as differing cultural or ethnic backgrounds.
word/document.xml
The communist characteristics included selflessness, enthusiasm for communism, physical health, collectivism, and<x22/>discipline.
The communist characteristics included selflessness, enthusiasm for communism, physical health, collectivism, and<x22/>discipline.
word/document.xml

There was also to be a new Soviet Woman, the likes of which the world had never seen before—self-sacrificing and devoted to revolutionary ideals.<x23/>By contrast, Hayek works dispassionately with human nature as he observes it to be—self-interested and individualistic.

There was also to be a new Soviet Woman, the likes of which the world had never seen before—self-sacrificing and devoted to revolutionary ideals.<x23/>By contrast, Hayek works dispassionately with human nature as he observes it to be—self-interested and individualistic.
word/document.xml
He views social engineering as more than merely impossible.
He views social engineering as more than merely impossible.
word/document.xml

It is also tremendously destructive because it is the antithesis of a natural society, and it destroys the liberal institutions that had evolved to serve individuals rather than the state.<x24/>Hayek knew first-hand the hideous consequences of central planning.

It is also tremendously destructive because it is the antithesis of a natural society, and it destroys the liberal institutions that had evolved to serve individuals rather than the state.<x24/>Hayek knew first-hand the hideous consequences of central planning.
word/document.xml
He had witnessed the devastation of classical liberalism by two world wars, but especially by World War I that had shattered the mold of the free market.
He had witnessed the devastation of classical liberalism by two world wars, but especially by World War I that had shattered the mold of the free market.
word/document.xml
Wartime government had clamped centralized control over the private sector to ensure the flow of armaments and other “necessary” goods.
Wartime government had clamped centralized control over the private sector to ensure the flow of armaments and other “necessary” goods.
word/document.xml
Money had been drastically inflated and reduced in value to pay for massive military build-ups.
Money had been drastically inflated and reduced in value to pay for massive military build-ups.
word/document.xml
War strangled the flow of free trade, which classical liberals thought was a prerequisite to peace between nations, as well as the prosperity of individuals.
War strangled the flow of free trade, which classical liberals thought was a prerequisite to peace between nations, as well as the prosperity of individuals.
word/document.xml

Hayek watched as the centralizing machine of 20th-century statism destroyed the promise of 19th -century classical liberalism.<x25/>In rebuttal to constructivism, Austrian economists describe how institutions in a healthy society arise spontaneously.

Hayek watched as the centralizing machine of 20th-century statism destroyed the promise of 19th -century classical liberalism.<x25/>In rebuttal to constructivism, Austrian economists describe how institutions in a healthy society arise spontaneously.
word/document.xml
The descriptions often begin with simplistic models to illustrate a basic principle or point—how a path is forged through a field, for example.
The descriptions often begin with simplistic models to illustrate a basic principle or point—how a path is forged through a field, for example.
word/document.xml
One person takes the shortest route across an overgrown field, and his passage leaves a crude trail of trampled grass behind.
One person takes the shortest route across an overgrown field, and his passage leaves a crude trail of trampled grass behind.
word/document.xml
As a matter of convenience, the next person who crosses the field uses the rough path, which becomes more clearly established as a result.
As a matter of convenience, the next person who crosses the field uses the rough path, which becomes more clearly established as a result.
word/document.xml
Each person who subsequently crosses contributes to making the path more distinct and easier to walk.
Each person who subsequently crosses contributes to making the path more distinct and easier to walk.
word/document.xml
No one constructs the path intentionally or as a service to other people; it is simply in each person’s self-interest to use the easiest route across the field.
No one constructs the path intentionally or as a service to other people; it is simply in each person’s self-interest to use the easiest route across the field.
word/document.xml

Nevertheless, the self-interested reinforcement of the path benefits everyone who walks the field thereafter.<x26/>One of Mises’s earliest works, <g7>Nation, State and Economy </g7>(1919) analyzes how much more complex social phenomena—such as language—were also the unintended consequences of individual interactions.

Nevertheless, the self-interested reinforcement of the path benefits everyone who walks the field thereafter.<x26/>One of Mises’s earliest works, <g7>Nation, State and Economy </g7>(1919) analyzes how much more complex social phenomena—such as language—were also the unintended consequences of individual interactions.
word/document.xml
No committee or central authority decided to invent human speech or to publish a dictionary, let alone to design a specific language like English.
No committee or central authority decided to invent human speech or to publish a dictionary, let alone to design a specific language like English.
word/document.xml
Without benefit of law, individuals began communicating in order to get what they wanted from each other.
Without benefit of law, individuals began communicating in order to get what they wanted from each other.
word/document.xml
The sounds being uttered gradually became more redefined and varied, even as the meanings of specific sounds became more widely recognized.
The sounds being uttered gradually became more redefined and varied, even as the meanings of specific sounds became more widely recognized.
word/document.xml

Language evolved.<x27/>Hayek develops a similarly sophisticated system of social theory to explain how all of society’s institutions naturally evolve from the bottom up—from the voluntary and unplanned interactions of individuals—rather than from the top down—from experts or the powerful who imposed their will.

Language evolved.<x27/>Hayek develops a similarly sophisticated system of social theory to explain how all of society’s institutions naturally evolve from the bottom up—from the voluntary and unplanned interactions of individuals—rather than from the top down—from experts or the powerful who imposed their will.
word/document.xml
Natural institutions, Hayek maintains, are the collective but unintended results of human interaction:
Natural institutions, Hayek maintains, are the collective but unintended results of human interaction:
word/document.xml
“the result of human action but not of human design.”
“the result of human action but not of human design.”
word/document.xml
Even complex social<x28/>phenomena—such as writing, religion, or money—are the unintended consequences of human interaction.
Even complex social<x28/>phenomena—such as writing, religion, or money—are the unintended consequences of human interaction.
word/document.xml
The alleged efficiency of government programs paled by comparison, to say the least.<x29/>Constructivists counter-argue that an unplanned society is chaotic and wasteful.
The alleged efficiency of government programs paled by comparison, to say the least.<x29/>Constructivists counter-argue that an unplanned society is chaotic and wasteful.
word/document.xml
With sufficient knowledge and a scientific approach, they believed a perfectly efficient society could be engineered.
With sufficient knowledge and a scientific approach, they believed a perfectly efficient society could be engineered.
word/document.xml
No surpluses, no scarcities, no waste, no unemployment.
No surpluses, no scarcities, no waste, no unemployment.
word/document.xml
Stock markets would not crash, and currencies would not fluctuate, except when they were supposed to do so.
Stock markets would not crash, and currencies would not fluctuate, except when they were supposed to do so.
word/document.xml

Society could be constructed so that its members walked in unison toward the same allegedly desirable social goals, just as they had marched in unison as soldiers toward victory in war.<x30/>Mises’s answer to constructivists would recast the concept of individualism.

Society could be constructed so that its members walked in unison toward the same allegedly desirable social goals, just as they had marched in unison as soldiers toward victory in war.<x30/>Mises’s answer to constructivists would recast the concept of individualism.
word/document.xml
<g8>The New Austrian Individualism</g8><x31/>A new conception of individualism arose in response to a theory that accompanied constructivism.
<g8>The New Austrian Individualism</g8><x31/>A new conception of individualism arose in response to a theory that accompanied constructivism.
word/document.xml
Social holism became popular in the early twentieth century.
Social holism became popular in the early twentieth century.
word/document.xml
Social holism claims that systems must be viewed as wholes rather than as collections of their parts, and a whole’s dynamic differs from the sum of its parts.
Social holism claims that systems must be viewed as wholes rather than as collections of their parts, and a whole’s dynamic differs from the sum of its parts.
word/document.xml
In short, the collective is greater than and different from the units that comprise it.
In short, the collective is greater than and different from the units that comprise it.
word/document.xml
A holistic analysis of society usually begins with a study of the collective, not the individual, and it assumes that the behavior of the individual is determined by the collective.
A holistic analysis of society usually begins with a study of the collective, not the individual, and it assumes that the behavior of the individual is determined by the collective.
word/document.xml
Individual behavior is defined by the category or properties of the class that is its context.
Individual behavior is defined by the category or properties of the class that is its context.
word/document.xml
Society is more than the sum total of the individuals who constitute it.<x32/>Austrian economists claim the opposite.
Society is more than the sum total of the individuals who constitute it.<x32/>Austrian economists claim the opposite.
word/document.xml
Society results from and it is explained by the behavior of the individuals who collectively <g9>are </g9>society.
Society results from and it is explained by the behavior of the individuals who collectively <g9>are </g9>society.
word/document.xml
Society has no independent existence apart from its individual members, all of whom act on their self-interest.
Society has no independent existence apart from its individual members, all of whom act on their self-interest.
word/document.xml

Self-interest is not equivalent to selfishness, however, as traditionally selfless acts—giving to charity, helping a neighbor, sacrificing for family—are frequently viewed by individuals as behavior that enriches life.

Self-interest is not equivalent to selfishness, however, as traditionally selfless acts—giving to charity, helping a neighbor, sacrificing for family—are frequently viewed by individuals as behavior that enriches life.
word/document.xml

In what seems like a paradox to some, traditionally selfless acts are often undertaken as a matter of self-interest.<x33/>Marxists accuse those who reduce society to individuals of being atomistic; that is, they are said to splinter society into unconnected and isolated units so that society does not truly exist.

In what seems like a paradox to some, traditionally selfless acts are often undertaken as a matter of self-interest.<x33/>Marxists accuse those who reduce society to individuals of being atomistic; that is, they are said to splinter society into unconnected and isolated units so that society does not truly exist.
word/document.xml
In response, some Marxists go so far as to assert that it is the individual, and not society, who is the true abstraction.
In response, some Marxists go so far as to assert that it is the individual, and not society, who is the true abstraction.
word/document.xml
That is, individuals do not exist without a surrounding society that defines them and constructs them.
That is, individuals do not exist without a surrounding society that defines them and constructs them.
word/document.xml
Mises observed of this position, “The notion of an individual, say the critics, is an empty abstraction.
Mises observed of this position, “The notion of an individual, say the critics, is an empty abstraction.
word/document.xml

Real man is necessarily always a member of a social whole.”<x34/>Karl Marx argues a point similar to this by using a Robinson Crusoe scenario, which is a popular way to construct an argument about human nature from its absolute basics—man in isolation.

Real man is necessarily always a member of a social whole.”<x34/>Karl Marx argues a point similar to this by using a Robinson Crusoe scenario, which is a popular way to construct an argument about human nature from its absolute basics—man in isolation.
word/document.xml
An individual who is born and abandoned on a desert island, Marx contends, will be more of a potential human being than an<x35/>actual one.
An individual who is born and abandoned on a desert island, Marx contends, will be more of a potential human being than an<x35/>actual one.
word/document.xml
(Some socialists, like Hegel, argue that man himself was an abstraction.)
(Some socialists, like Hegel, argue that man himself was an abstraction.)
word/document.xml
Marx makes a distinction between "human nature in general" and "human nature as modified" by historical periods of epochs.
Marx makes a distinction between "human nature in general" and "human nature as modified" by historical periods of epochs.
word/document.xml
Two types of human drives exist: ones that are fixed like hunger, and ones that "owe their origin to certain social structures and certain conditions of production and communication."
Two types of human drives exist: ones that are fixed like hunger, and ones that "owe their origin to certain social structures and certain conditions of production and communication."
word/document.xml
Marx’s point is that, beyond inherent characteristics like instinct, human nature is a social construct defined by social context; society creates the humanity of its individual members.
Marx’s point is that, beyond inherent characteristics like instinct, human nature is a social construct defined by social context; society creates the humanity of its individual members.
word/document.xml

This meant society could construct what Marx considers to be the right type of humanity—like the new Soviet man—if the institutions of society are thoroughly oriented toward achieving this goal.<x36/>Classical liberals argue the opposite.

This meant society could construct what Marx considers to be the right type of humanity—like the new Soviet man—if the institutions of society are thoroughly oriented toward achieving this goal.<x36/>Classical liberals argue the opposite.
word/document.xml
A person raised in isolation will still be a realized human being with human characteristics far beyond a drive for the basic needs of survival.
A person raised in isolation will still be a realized human being with human characteristics far beyond a drive for the basic needs of survival.
word/document.xml
For example, Crusoe will have a scale of preferences that economists call marginal utility, and he will act to achieve the highest one first; he will get water to drink before water to bathe in.
For example, Crusoe will have a scale of preferences that economists call marginal utility, and he will act to achieve the highest one first; he will get water to drink before water to bathe in.
word/document.xml
He will have curiosity and an ability to feel sorrow.
He will have curiosity and an ability to feel sorrow.
word/document.xml
Without social interaction, huge parts of his potential will never develop, of course, but this does not make him less human or make him lack an individual will and personality.
Without social interaction, huge parts of his potential will never develop, of course, but this does not make him less human or make him lack an individual will and personality.
word/document.xml
Collectives offer incentives for specific behaviors, but they do not define humanity.
Collectives offer incentives for specific behaviors, but they do not define humanity.
word/document.xml
Human beings and their innate nature define collectives.
Human beings and their innate nature define collectives.
word/document.xml

Under Mises’s analysis, this simple argument evolves into a sweeping new approach to individualism.<x37/>As a general social theory, individualism means the advocacy of individual freedom as opposed to the power of a collective, especially the state.

Under Mises’s analysis, this simple argument evolves into a sweeping new approach to individualism.<x37/>As a general social theory, individualism means the advocacy of individual freedom as opposed to the power of a collective, especially the state.

As a personal matter, it means people make their own peaceful choices and take responsibility for them.
